@sekikn if you want to disable the tests, make sure that everything is covered by (unit)tests. Ie. this probably means writing other tests. Some work indeed, hence we havent done so yet. It might be  better to split up the tests on Travis so they only run once in the matrix...
@artwr do you have any comments here?
LGTM merged

I agree raising an exception would be the proper thing to do. Regarding the issue with tasks that return large xcoms:

> you must change your task behaviour for your DAG to terminate

I think this is the answer. Anything else would be trying to accomodate use cases that are beyond the scope of airflow. To quote [the airflow docs](https://github.com/apache/incubator-airflow/blob/master/docs/index.rst#beyond-the-horizon):

> Airflow is not a data streaming solution. Tasks do not move data from one to the other (though tasks can exchange metadata!).

If you have tasks that are returning values larger than some reasonable xcom size limit, you probably should rethink how your DAGs are working.
Done. Didn't think it was necessary for such a small typo. Anyways, hope its good now!

Hey, thanks for submitting this. This is a huge gap right now that is preventing us from using Airflow for Dataflow jobs. That said, I wonder if you've considered exposing more than just the last line? My (limited) understanding of Dataflow is that there are both client (i.e. Airflow-side) and server (i.e. Data flow machine) logs.

This patch appears to expose only the final line of the client-side logs. Is this really sufficient to triage failures? What do you think about exposing all client-side logs? What about exposing server-side logs as well, which will likely have the actual relevant information (e.g. stack traces, whatever) that's needed to debug issues.

Echoing the need / desire for making Airflow work around daylight savings - my use case, which I can't imagine is so uncommon, is that we produce reports for executives that expect to see those reports in a specific time zone (in this case, Eastern time)  So, they want to see 'all widgets sold on October 19', and expect that 'October 19' means all times between 2017-10-19T04:00+00:00  and 2017-10-20T04:00+00:00 . So I could set my Airflow scheduler to run at "04:00" UTC each day, but then this breaks when daylight savings rolls around..

Root Cause Analysis:
> This is a problem with the flask_admin package. When returning it return the ids to the @action function for the TaskInstance model, values which have a period ('.') in them are duplicated. I'm going to look into this, but it isn't a problem with airflow.
> Looking deeper into flask_admin I think this is the reason. flask_admin runs an escape function in it's get_pk_value in the flask_admin.contrib.sqla.view.ModelView class (https://github.com/flask-admin/flask-admin/blob/master/flask_admin/contrib/sqla/view.py#L399-L407). That escape function is imported from flask_admin.contrib.sqla.tools which imports it from flask_admin.tools. It escapes the CHAR_ESCAPE with two CHAR_ESCAPE's values. 
Those CHAR_ESCAPE values are set as '.':
https://github.com/flask-admin/flask-admin/blob/master/flask_admin/tools.py#L7
Here's the escape function:
https://github.com/flask-admin/flask-admin/blob/master/flask_admin/tools.py#L104-L107
That's then called in the BaseModelView.index_view method here:
https://github.com/flask-admin/flask-admin/blob/master/flask_admin/model/base.py#L1975
And that is then inherited in the flask_admin.contrib.sqla.view.ModelView class. That is then the base class for airflow.www.AirflowModelView, which is the base class for airflow.www.ModelViewOnly, which is the base class for airflow.www.TaskInstanceModelView.

This causes any '.' characters in the at least compound primary keys to become duplicated. Given that all SubDAG's are enforced to have a period in the dag_id column and that the primary key for the task_instance model is execution_date, dag_id, and task_id, the returned dag_id given to the action is always incorrect.

Considerations for solution:
> We could possibly reach out to the flask_admin developers to understand why they are doing this escaping. However, given that this seems very intentional, an airflow side fix may be the better solution. A final drastic alternative to change the separator from a '.' to another character.

@bolkedebruin I'll spend some time to make an explicit test of the values returned to the @action functions.

The problem that we were seeing was that some flakiness in one of our DAGs resulted in tasks being removed and then coming back. The removed tasks would receive a "REMOVED" status but then, when they came back, they would forever stay "REMOVED" instead of getting retried.
